title: Psychological Disorders II. Group Project. Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Article Title
Stressor-Cortisol Concordance Among Individuals at Clinical High-Risk for Psychosis: Novel Findings from the NAPLS Cohort

title: Psychological Disorders II. Group Project. Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Key Terms

Concordance



Hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal(HPA) axis The central physiological mechanism linking psychosocial stress to the onset and exacerbation of schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders



HPA dysregulation
HPA axis
Prodrome/ Prodromal

title: Psychological Disorders II. Group Project. Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text: Background

title: Psychological Disorders II. Group Project. Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Question

Broad Question

The neural diathesis stress model and clinical risk for psychosis Abnormalities in the HPA axis , places individuals at increased vulnerability for psychosis

Specific Question

Determining the extent to which HPA axis responsivity in at-risk youth predicts clinical outcome is important

CHR youth who later converted to psychosis would show:

Greater exposure and distress in relation to psychosocial stressors
Elevated basal cortisol
Higher stressor-cortisol concordance relative to healthy controls

CHR nonconverters

Would be intermediate to CHR converters subgroups and healthy controls



Measurement positive symptom progression

title: Psychological Disorders II. Group Project. Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Methods
Utilizing data from North American Prodrome Longitudinal Study 2 NAPLS 2
Subjects

662 participants
Age
CHR subjects



Exclusion criteria 1. Axis-1 psychotic disorder 2. Permitted treatment with antipsychotic medication provided full psychotic symptoms were not present at the time of medication commencement
Initial assessment 1. Conducted by clinically trained interviewers


Prodromal syndromes were assessed using the Criteria of Prodromal Syndromes (COPS) based on the Structured Interview for Prodromal Syndromes(SIPS)
Psychiatric diagnoses were determined via the Structured Clinical Interview (SCID) for DSM-IV


Help Seeking
Met criteria for one or more prodromal syndromes 1. Attenuated psychotic symptoms 2. Brief intermittent psychotic symptoms 3. Substantial functional decline combine with a first degree relative with a psychotic disorder or schizotypal personality disorder in individuals younger than 18 years.

Question

Broad Question

Specific Question

CHR youth who later converted to psychosis would show:

title: Psychological Disorders II. Group Project. Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Methods
Utilizing data from North American Prodrome Longitudinal Study 2 NAPLS 2
Subjects

662 participants
Age
CHR subjects



Exclusion criteria 1. Axis-1 psychotic disorder 2. Permitted treatment with antipsychotic medication provided full psychotic symptoms were not present at the time of medication commencement
Initial assessment 1. Conducted by clinically trained interviewers



Prodromal syndromes were assessed using the Criteria of Prodromal Syndromes (COPS) based on the Structured Interview for Prodromal Syndromes(SIPS)
Psychiatric diagnoses were determined via the Structured Clinical Interview (SCID) for DSM-IV



Help Seeking

References
Environmental Protection Agency(03/13/2023). Endocrine Disruption Overview of the Endocrine System. https://www.epa.gov/endocrine-disruption/overview-endocrine-system
Jubb. (2016). Molecular neuroendocrinology : from genome to physiology (Murphy & H. Gainer, Eds.). Wiley Blackwell. Page 94 Page 122
Lupien, Maheu, F., Tu, M., Fiocco, A., & Schramek, T. E. (2007). The effects of stress and stress hormones on human cognition: Implications for the field of brain and cognition. Brain and Cognition, 65(3), 209–237. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.bandc.2007.02.007

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text: Hypothalamus & Pituitary Gland

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Hypothalamus
The hypothalamus monitors the internal systems keeping homeostasis through its neural connections, controlling the release of various hormones.
It regulates sleep, hunger, thirst, body temperature, blood pressure, hormone secretion, and water balance. The hypothalamus interacts mostly with the nervous system, and the endocrine system, stimulating organs to release hormones. It is only the size of a dime.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Pituitary Gland
it is sometimes designated as the master gland. It is about the size of an acorn. The pituitary is actually two glands in one, the posterior and anterior.
The posterior pituitary manufactures no hormones of its own, but stores two hormones that are initially secreted in a part of the brain known as the hypothalamus. The hormones are oxytocin, which is believed to stimulate labor at the end of pregnancy, and vasopressin, which helps the body retains its fluids.
The anterior pituitary controls the overall growth of the body. The anterior lobe originates embryonically from the epithelial lining of the pharynx. The anterior portion has many functions and several of its hormones have been isolated.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Thank You !!
Thank you for following along during our presentation

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text: The central physiological mechanism linking psychosocial stress to the onset and exacerbation of schizophrenia and related psychotic disorders

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Hypothalamus Part I
Hypothalamus - The hypothalamus links our endocrine and nervous systems together. The hypothalamus drives the endocrine system.(EPA, 2023)
The hypothalamus monitors the internal systems keeping homeostasis through its neural connections, controlling the release of various hormones.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Hypothalamus Part II
It regulates sleep, hunger, thirst, body temperature, blood pressure, hormone secretion, and water balance. The hypothalamus interacts mostly with the nervous system, and the endocrine system, stimulating organs to release hormones. It is only the size of a dime.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Pituitary Gland Part I
It is sometimes designated as the master gland. It is about the size of an acorn. The pituitary is actually two glands in one, the posterior and anterior.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Pituitary Gland Part II
The posterior pituitary manufactures no hormones of its own, but stores two hormones that are initially secreted in a part of the brain known as the hypothalamus. The hormones are oxytocin, which is believed to stimulate labor at the end of pregnancy, and vasopressin, which helps the body retains its fluids.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Pituitary Gland Part III
The anterior pituitary controls the overall growth of the body. The anterior portion has many functions and several of its hormones have been isolated.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part I
The body activates stress systems on exposure to a stressor; the autonomic nervous system initiates a rapid and relatively short‐lived ‘fight‐or‐flight’ response, whilst the HPA axis is slower, instigating a more protracted response.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part II
Tight regulation of the HPA axis is core to the long‐term control of systems governing stress responsivity.
Following a stressor, the neuropeptides corticotropin‐releasing hormone (CRH) and argi-nine vasopressin (AVP) are released from the paraventricular nucleus (PVN) of the hypothala-mus into the portal vessel system.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part III
These bind specific receptors (the CRHR1 and V1b receptors for CRH and AVP, respectively) in the anterior pituitary that stimulate the release of adreno-corticotropic hormone (ACTH). (Jubb, 2016)

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part IV
Schematic representation of the hypothalamic-pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis. Following the perception of a stressor, the hypothalamus releases CRF, which activates the pituitary and leads to secretion of ACTH. The levels of ACTH are detected by the adrenal cortex which then secretes glucocorticoids and catecholamines

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Pituitary Gland Part IV
The anterior pituitary contains endocrine cells which produce several hormones (adrenocorticotropic hormone [ACTH], thyroid‐stimulating hormone [TSH], follicle‐stimulating hormone [FSH], luteinizing hormone [LH[, growth hormone [GH], prolactin [PRL])

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part V
This in turn acts on the adrenal cortex to synthesize and release glucocorticoid hormones, i.e. cortisol/corticosterone. These then mobilize glucose from energy stores and increase cardiovascular tone, among further widespread effects.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part VI
Feedback loops, primarily mediated at the PVN and pituitary through glucocorticoid receptors (GR), restrain the responsiveness of the HPA axis to reset the system to baseline activity (Figure 6.1).
In sum, the forward loop prepares the organism to anticipate and respond optimally to a threat, while the feedback loop ensures returning efficiently to a homeostatic balance when it is no longer challenged

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part I
The body activates stress systems on exposure to a stressor; the autonomic nervous system initiates a rapid and relatively short‐lived ‘fight‐or‐flight’ response, whilst the HPA axis is slower, instigating a more protracted response.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part II
Tight regulation of the HPA axis is core to the long‐term control of systems governing stress responsivity.
Following a stressor, the neuropeptides corticotropin‐releasing hormone (CRH) and argi-nine vasopressin (AVP) are released from the paraventricular nucleus (PVN) of the hypothala-mus into the portal vessel system.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part IV
Schematic representation of the hypothalamic-pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis. Following the perception of a stressor, the hypothalamus releases CRF, which activates the pituitary and leads to secretion of ACTH. The levels of ACTH are detected by the adrenal cortex which then secretes glucocorticoids and catecholamines

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part V
This in turn acts on the adrenal cortex to synthesize and release glucocorticoid hormones, i.e. cortisol/corticosterone. These then mobilize glucose from energy stores and increase cardiovascular tone, among further widespread effects.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
HPA Part VI
Feedback loops, primarily mediated at the PVN and pituitary through glucocorticoid receptors (GR), restrain the responsiveness of the HPA axis to reset the system to baseline activity (Figure 6.1).
In sum, the forward loop prepares the organism to anticipate and respond optimally to a threat, while the feedback loop ensures returning efficiently to a homeostatic balance when it is no longer challenged

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Pituitary Gland Part IV
Under tight control of hormones produced by the neurons in hypothalamic nuclei, and delivered to the anterior pituitary via the portal system, ‘skipping’ the general circulation. (Jubb 2016)

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
The Hypothalamus, Pituitary Gland, Thyroid Gland
The Adrenal Glands, Pancreas, Gonads
For example: Pancreas - The pancreas is responsible for producing glucagon and insulin. Both hormones help regulate the concentration of glucose (sugar) in the blood.
United States Environmental Protection Agency

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
The Endocrine System Part I
The endocrine system, made up of all the body’s different hormones, regulates all biological processes in the body.
Including the development of the brain and nervous system, the growth and function of the reproductive system, as well as the metabolism and blood sugar levels.(EPA, 2023 )

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Endocrine System Part II
The Hypothalamus, Pituitary Gland, Thyroid Gland
The Adrenal Glands, Pancreas, Gonads Female Ovaries, Male Testis
For example: Pancreas - The pancreas is responsible for producing glucagon and insulin. Both hormones help regulate the concentration of glucose (sugar) in the blood.
United States Environmental Protection Agency Endocrine System

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text: Question

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text: Question

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Specific Question
Examining stressor-cortisol concordance among youth at clinical high-risk (CHR) for psychosis in the North American Prodrome Longitudinal Study 2 (NAPLS 2) and the relationship with clinical outcome.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Specific Question
Determining the extent to which HPA axis responsivity in at-risk youth predicts clinical outcome is important

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Broad Question
Elevations in basal cortisol levels have been reported among individuals at-risk for psychosis, the extent to which this represents hyperresponsivity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis to psychosocial stressors encountered in the natural environment is currently unclear.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Specific Question
Authors Hypothesized Three Predicted Outcomes for CHR youth who converted to psychosis
CHR youth who later converted to psychosis would show:

Greater exposure and distress in relation to psychosocial stressors
Elevated basal cortisol
Higher stressor-cortisol concordance relative to healthy controls

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Specific Question
Authors Hypothesized the Following Predicted Outcome for CH youth “nonconverters”
CHR nonconverters: Would be intermediate to CHR converters subgroups and healthy controls. Determined by measurement of positive symptom progression.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Methods
CHR Subjects cont’d

Help Seeking
Met criteria for one or more prodromal syndromes

Attenuated psychotic symptoms
Brief intermittent psychotic symptoms
Substantial functional decline combine with a first degree relative with a psychotic disorder or schizotypal personality disorder in individuals younger than 18 years.

title: Cortisol Concordance: A Slide Deck
text:
Methods
Healthy Controls

Exclusion criteria:

Non psychotic psychiatric disorders were permitted
Substance dependence in the past 6 months
IQ < 70
Neurological disorder

text:

The neural diathesis stress model and clinical risk for psychosis Abnormalities in the HPA axis , places individuals at increased vulnerability for psychosis
